stem: The infection control nurse is reviewing the profiles of three clients with acute hepatitis. Based on the documented transmission history and immunization status in the EHR, indicate the appropriate classification for each Hepatitis type.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Case 1: Mr. Lopez (28 years old) recently returned from a 3-week backpacking trip. He reports consuming street food and raw shellfish. He is now jaundiced and reports dark urine. 
Case 2: Ms. Sarah (32 years old) is a nurse who sustained a deep needle stick injury from a patient with a known history of chronic liver disease while working in a high-risk unit. 
Case 3: Mr. Jax (45 years old) has a 10-year history of intravenous drug use. He states he has 'shared needles in the past' and was recently told his liver enzymes are in the 800s.

tabs.content:

tabs.title: Prevention Log
tabs.content: Review of the medical records indicates that only Mr. Lopez and Ms. Sarah have documentation of a completed vaccine series for their respective conditions. There is no record of a vaccine for the condition identified in Case 3.

rationale.correct: Hepatitis A is transmitted via the fecal-oral route (e.g., contaminated food/shellfish) and has a highly effective vaccine. Hepatitis B is transmitted via blood and body fluids (e.g., needle sticks) and also has a vaccine. Hepatitis C is primarily blood-borne (e.g., IV drug use/needle sharing) but currently has NO available vaccine, although it can be treated with antiviral medications.
clinicalPearls: Vowels come from the Bowel: Hep A and E are fecal-oral.
Hep B stands for 'Blood and Body Fluids'.
Hep B and C are the primary causes of chronic cirrhosis and liver cancer.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking that all forms of viral hepatitis have vaccines.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that Hepatitis C is the most common reason for liver transplant and still does not have a preventative vaccine.
